original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares close at one-week low due to weak macroeconomic sentiments
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT –Sri Lanka’s shares closed at over a one-week low on Wednesday as negative macroeconomic sentiment continues to affect the market, prompting investors to take a cautious approach until more policy clarity is provided, an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index (ASPI) was down 0.58 percent or 54.11 points to 9,291.42 the lowest since April 03.
“Investors are waiting for clear direction after the IMF comments regarding the local debt restructuring,” an analyst said.
“The debt restructuring fear has caused the banking sector shares to go down, which is dragging the market for the last few days.”
The market generated a turnover of 632 billion rupees, below the daily average of 1.7 billion rupees and the lowest since April 03.

Sri Lanka’s Governor, Nandalal Weerasinghe, stated that the country would not restructure Treasury bills outside of central bank holdings and would engage with major T-bond holders for voluntary ‘optimization.’
Meanwhile, the IMF deal is scheduled to be presented to Parliament on April 25th.
There was a net foreign outflow of 44.2 million rupees, bringing the total net foreign outflow for the year so far to 3.3 billion rupees.
Top losers during trade were Expolanka holdings, Hatton National Bank and Sampath Bank. (Colombo/ April19/2023)
